datafield.subfield: Black hole chemistry: thermodynamics with Lambda

We review recent developments on the thermodynamics of black holes in extended phase space, where the cosmological constant is interpreted as thermodynamic pressure and treated as a thermodynamic variable in its own right. In this approach, the mass of the black hole is no longer regarded as internal energy, rather it is identified with the chemical enthalpy. This leads to an extended dictionary for black hole thermodynamic quantities, in particular a notion of thermodynamic volume emerges for a given black hole spacetime. This volume is conjectured to satisfy the reverse isoperimetric inequality—an inequality imposing a bound on the amount of entropy black hole can carry for a fixed thermodynamic volume. New thermodynamic phase transitions naturally emerge from these identifications. Namely, we show that black holes can be understood from the viewpoint of chemistry, in terms of concepts such as Van der Waals fluids, reentrant phase transitions, and triple points. We also review the recent attempts at extending the AdS/CFT dictionary in this setting, discuss the connections with horizon thermodynamics, applications to Lifshitz spacetimes, and outline possible future directions in this field.
Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics - 31 Caroline St. N. -Waterloo - Ontario N2L 2Y5 - Canada

The surface gravity κ is constant over the event horizon of a stationary black hole

For a rotating charged black hole with a mass M, an angular momentum J, and a charge Q, \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\delta M=\frac{\kappa}{8\pi G}\delta A+ \Omega \delta J+ \Phi \delta Q,\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag
2.1 } \end{equation*} where κ is its surface gravity, \Omega its angular velocity, and \Phi its electric potential
Hawking's area theorem: \delta A\geqslant 0, i.e. the area A of a black hole's event horizon can never decrease
It is impossible to reduce the surface gravity κ to zero in a finite number of steps

Hawking's proof applies to black hole spacetimes that satisfy certain reasonable assumptions, namely, that the spacetime on and outside the future event horizon is a regular predictable space, and that the stress-energy tensor satisfies the null energy condition, {{T}_{ab}}{{k}^{a}}{{k}^{b}}\geqslant 0, for arbitrary null vector ka

Here, \delta {{N}_{j}} describes changing number of particles of a given species and {{\mu}_{j}} is the corresponding chemical potential. Similarly the term \Phi \delta Q allows for the possibility of variable electrostatic energy
Note that in d dimensions the gravitational constant Gd has units of [length]d-4, which will be relevant when we consider the AdS/CFT correspondence in section, 5: #cqgaa5c69s5
In thermodynamics this relation is known as the Gibbs-Duhem relation
in the context of black hole physics this relation was originally derived by Smarr [, 32: #cqgaa5c69bib032a], and is often simply referred to as a Smarr formula

While one might, a priori, consider associating black hole pressure with a positive cosmological constant, there are a number of subtleties and unresolved issues in black hole thermodynamics in such spacetimes. We shall consider this topic in section, 6: #cqgaa5c69s6
See also [, 46: #cqgaa5c69bib046] for a treatment of the Smarr formula and first law with fixed \Lambda and the corresponding AdS/CFT interpretation

This includes lower-dimensional gravity in d = 2, 3 [, 56: #cqgaa5c69bib056]. Let us also remark that there has recently been an investigation of a dynamical \Lambda that arises as an integration constant in two spacetime dimensions [, 57: #cqgaa5c69bib057]. The cosmological constant behaves as a U(1) charge with a confining potential, necessitating a novel (gravitational) Born-Infeld boundary term in the action. The relationship with the d\to 2 limit of the Smarr relation (, 2.19: #cqgaa5c69eqn019) [, 56: #cqgaa5c69bib056] has yet to be explored

Note that in the absence of magnetic fields the second electromagnetic invariant \tilde{F} does not contribute and is often omitted in the literature. The simplified Lagrangian (, 2.40: #cqgaa5c69eqn040) without \tilde{F} is then promoted to higher dimensions and called Born-Infeld theory, e.g. [, 84: #cqgaa5c69bib084]. This is to be compared to the approach taken in string theory, e.g. [, 85: #cqgaa5c69bib085], where the Born-Infeld action is identified with {{\mathcal{L}}_{\text{BI}}}\propto \sqrt{\det \left({{g}_{ab}}+\frac{1}{b}{{F}_{ab}}\right)} in all dimensions
Note that to use definition (, 3.1: #cqgaa5c69eqn043) one does not need to know the full AdS solution

a perturbative expansion in P is sufficient. See also section, 6: #cqgaa5c69s6 for a similar construction in asymptotically dS spacetimes. Other (mostly geometric) definitions of black hole volume are discussed later in this section

It has been further argued [, 95: #cqgaa5c69bib095] that the volume in the asymptotically flat limit is either non-universal or that one must come to grips with the fact that an asymptotically flat black hole can have more than one well-defined volume. We disagree—the definition (, 3.1: #cqgaa5c69eqn043) is unambiguous and does not imply multiple volumes in the flat space limit. Moreover, we consider the fact that the thermodynamic volume has a smooth non-vanishing limit for asymptotically flat black holes to be not a drawback but rather a natural feature. It is our everyday experience that volume of a body has meaning and can be non-trivial even in the absence of external pressure. Since in our setting \Lambda is variable, the asymptotically flat black hole with P = 0 just corresponds to a 'fine-tuned' state and there is no reason why its volume should be trivial. Fluctuations in pressure will lead to black holes for which their volume can be calculated from the definition (, 3.1: #cqgaa5c69eqn043). Requiring a smooth limit then yields a non-trivial volume for asymptotically flat black holes

Note that the same inequality can be extended to all black holes, with {{\omega}_{d}} replaced by the corresponding unit volume of the space transverse to the event horizon. For example, for topological AdS black holes (k\ne 1 in (, 2.11: #cqgaa5c69eqn011)), {{\omega}_{d}} would be replaced by the corresponding volume of the constant curvature space \omega _{d}^{(k)} [, 40: #cqgaa5c69bib040a]
Similar types of black hole spacetimes have been obtained where the inequality remains to be checked [, 102: #cqgaa5c69bib102,, 103: #cqgaa5c69bib103]
Lorentzian Taub-NUT solutions have many peculiar properties and are usually discarded as physically irrelevant
however this viewpoint has recently been challenged [, 105: #cqgaa5c69bib105]

Although natural in the case of spherical Taub-NUT solutions [, 110: #cqgaa5c69bib110], a similar restriction is often imposed for the planar and hyperbolic counterparts as well [, 111: #cqgaa5c69bib111,, 112: #cqgaa5c69bib112]

Expressions similar to the quantity (, 3.20: #cqgaa5c69eqn062) can be also written for Lovelock thermodynamic potentials {{ \Psi }^{k}} [, 80: #cqgaa5c69bib080] that appear in the thermodynamic first law of Lovelock black holes, (, 2.37: #cqgaa5c69eqn037)
for a torus, Ak=0 = AB, where A and B are the sides of the torus. There is no simple formula for Ak=-1

The fact that this ratio has no dependence on black hole charge Q is unsurprising by dimensional arguments. However, there is currently no obvious explanation as to why both ratios are the same. This is true, however, only in four dimensions—for charged-AdS black holes in higher dimensions the ratio becomes {{P}_{c}}{{v}_{c}}/{{T}_{c}}=(2d-5)/(4d-8) [, 83: #cqgaa5c69bib083]

The critical exponents characterize the behavior of various physical quantities in the vicinity of a critical point. Specifically, denoting by t = T/Tc - 1, the critical exponents for the black hole are defined as follows [, 73: #cqgaa5c69bib073]:
Exponent α governs the behaviour of the specific heat at constant volume

Exponent β describes the behaviour of the order parameter \mathfrak{M}={{V}_{l}}-{{V}_{s}}, a difference between the volume of a large black hole Vl and the volume of a small black hole Vs on the given isotherm

\end{equation*} (Alternatively, one could define the order parameter as the difference between the specific volumes, \mathfrak{m}={{v}_{l}}-{{v}_{s}}.) Exponent γ determines the behaviour of the isothermal compressibility {{\kappa}_{T}}
see adiabatic compressibility {{\kappa}_{S}}, (, 3.18: #cqgaa5c69eqn060), discussed in section, 3: #cqgaa5c69s3. Exponent δ governs the following behaviour on the critical isotherm T = Tc:

As correctly pointed out in [, 142: #cqgaa5c69bib142,, 143: #cqgaa5c69bib143] Maxwell's equal area law is only qualitatively but not quantitatively right when imposed in the P - v plane. This is due to the fact that v\propto V/N where N is no longer a constant but N = N(r+)
The equal area law for the holographic entanglement entropy was studied in [, 144: #cqgaa5c69bib144]
Interestingly, no such phenomena seem to exist for Born-Infeld-AdS black holes described by (, 2.40: #cqgaa5c69eqn040) (with \tilde{F}=0) in higher dimensions [, 84: #cqgaa5c69bib084]
however see the corresponding footnote in section, 2: #cqgaa5c69s2
These latter objects exhibit a number of interesting features—for example their entropy becomes negative for certain choices of the parameters [, 173: #cqgaa5c69bib173]

Of course, the existence of an additional critical point makes the two diagrams displayed in figure, 8: #cqgaa5c69f08 fundamentally different. A semi-infinite coexistence line clearly separates two phases: to obtain liquid from solid we actually have to melt the crystal. There is no possibility of 'going around a critical point' as in the liquid/gas case where one can by choosing a 'clever path' avoid undergoing a first order phase transition
We refer the reader to citations of [, 47: #cqgaa5c69bib047,, 73: #cqgaa5c69bib073] for further directions and references
Typically characterized by 2 order parameters, this is a critical point where a coexistence line of second-order phase transition merges with a line of first-order phase transitions

As such, the aforementioned examples of heat engines that go around a loop in the P - V plane are, from the viewpoint of the boundary, going around the space of field theories rather than staying within one particular field theory [, 183: #cqgaa5c69bib183,, 191: #cqgaa5c69bib191]

How does the expression for G5 arise? Since we are compactifying a 10-dimensional space into \text{Ad}{{\text{S}}_{5}}\times {{S}^{5}}, we treat the 10-dimensional Newton constant G10 as the true gravitational constant. The corresponding Planck length is defined using the general relation {{\left(\ell _{Pl}^{(d)}\right)}^{d-2}}=\hbar {{G}_{d}} for 10 dimensions. To find the effective gravitational constant in 5 dimensions, we divide by the volume of the compactified space, i.e. {{G}_{5}}={{G}_{10}}/{{V}_{{{S}^{5}}}}, where {{V}_{{{S}^{5}}}}={{\pi}^{3}}{{l}^{5}} is the volume of the 5-dimensional sphere with radius l

Since the minimal surface area in an asymptotically AdS bulk (and thus also the entanglement entropy) is formally divergent, to obtain a finite result one needs to employ a due regularization procedure
To obtain a finite entanglement entropy, the area of the minimal surface in pure AdS was subtracted from the black hole configuration
Quintessence is a scalar field which can vary in space and time. It was proposed to explain dark energy, and is an alternative to the cosmological constant model
See [, 245: #cqgaa5c69bib245,, 246: #cqgaa5c69bib246] for recent developments on other peculiar features of asymptotically dS spacetimes
See e.g. [, 254: #cqgaa5c69bib254-, 256: #cqgaa5c69bib256] for a discussion of why a rather formal thermodynamics of inner horizons may play a role in understanding black hole microscopics
In the dS case such a quantity is 'conserved in space' (rather than in time) due to the spacelike character of the Killing field {{\partial}_{t}} in the region near infinity [, 257: #cqgaa5c69bib257]

This ad hoc postulate is not justified by anything apart from simplicity and the fact that it does not produce pathologies at least at first sight. For example, both effective temperature {{T}_{\text{eff}}} and effective volume {{V}_{\text{eff}}} are now now manifestly positive
This is a meaningful concept of quasi-local energy in spherically symmetric spacetimes [, 276: #cqgaa5c69bib276], evaluated on the black hole horizon
We refer to [, 93: #cqgaa5c69bib093] for a covariant treatment in more general setting of variable background fields
